question: Question_03_(e)
statement:
Let

\[S = \left\{[x_1, x_2, x_3]^T:\, x_1 + x_2 + x_3 = 0\right\}\]

be the subspace of vectors in $\mathbb R^3$ whose components sum to
zero.

\textbf{(e)} Let \emph{Q = I - P}. What kind of matrix is \emph{Q}? What
are \emph{N(Q)} and \emph{R(Q)}?
sols:
First, we show that \emph{Q} is a projection, that is
\emph{Q\textsuperscript{2} = Q}:

\[\displaystyle
Q^2 = (I-P)(I-P) = I-P-P+P^2 = I-P-P+P = I-P = Q\]

since \emph{P\textsuperscript{2} = P} because \emph{P} is a projection.

Next we show that \emph{N(Q) = R(P)}. So let \emph{x} be in the
nullspace of \emph{Q}. Then \emph{0 = Qx = (I-P)x = x-Px} and hence
\emph{Px = x} which implies in particular that \emph{x} is in the range
of \emph{P}. Next, let \emph{x} be in the range of \emph{P}, and choose
\emph{y} such that \emph{x = Py}. Multiplying both sides with \emph{P}
yields \emph{Px = P\textsuperscript{2}y = Py = x}, which we can rewrite
as \emph{(I-P)x = 0} and thus \emph{x} is in the nullspace of \emph{Q}.
Therefore \emph{N(Q) = R(P)}. But \emph{P} was chosen such that
\emph{R(P) = S} and hence

\[\displaystyle
N(Q) = R(P) = S\]

Interchanging the roles of \emph{P} and \emph{Q}, after all \emph{Q =
I-P} implies that \emph{P = I-Q}, we obtain that \emph{R(Q) = N(P)}. We
claim that \emph{N(P) = S\textsuperscript{T}}. This is quick since
\emph{Px = 0} is equivalent to saying that \emph{x} has no component in
\emph{S} which is equivalent to saying that \emph{x} is orthogonal to
\emph{S}. From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2012/Question_03_(a)}{part
(a)} we remember that the vector \emph{{[}1, 1, 1{]}\textsuperscript{T}}
spans the orthogonal complement of \emph{S} and hence

\[\displaystyle
R(Q) = S^T = \mathrm{span}\left\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{bmatrix}\right\}\]
hints:
Use that \emph{P\textsuperscript{2} = P} to show that
\emph{Q\textsuperscript{2} = Q}, that is, \emph{Q} is also a projection.

In fact, \emph{Q} is called the \emph{complementary projection of P}. As
such \emph{Q} swaps the range and nullspace of \emph{P} (why?).
